Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: On the Cutting Edge: A Community Resource Transforming Geoscience Education

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This project is expanding the work of the award-winning "On the Cutting Edge" program, and is continuing to provide a comprehensive, discipline-wide professional development program for current and future geoscience faculty. It is attempting to engage, through participation in face-to-face or online Cutting Edge workshop experiences, about half of the total number of US geoscience faculty in order to achieve a widespread and sustainable impact. It is expanding the segment of the faculty population who have had a first workshop experience, and is also providing geoscience faculty with advanced opportunities for learning that are also encouraging repeated participation in Cutting Edge activities, enabling ongoing learning, and resulting in increased changes in teaching practice among participants. The project is continuing an annual series of face-to-face workshops and is adding six virtual or hybrid workshops or other virtual events. It is introducing a number of new elements including 1) a stronger focus on improving introductory geoscience courses and increasing participation of faculty from two-year colleges, 2) revising the project website to include expanded community-authored and community-reviewed resources as well as improved methods for searching and obtaining previously submitted materials, 3) developing structured activities aimed specifically at enlarging and improving accessibility to the website, 4) incorporating a full research and evaluation program that not only is providing formative feedback to improve the program, but also is extending evaluation to assess the effect that the program has on teaching practice and student learning among the broader geoscience community. In particular, the project is attempting to determine what impact repeated participation in geoscience professional development has on individual teaching practice and on geoscience education nationwide, and what impact participation in an innovative and research-based community of geoscience educators has on faculty teaching effectiveness. The project is developing and disseminating best practices for the geosciences, however, many project activities are also being transferred to other STEM disciplines through publications, presentations, workshops, and through collaborations developed with SENCER and other organizations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
On the Cutting Edge is a comprehensive, discipline-wide professional development program for current and future geoscience faculty that offers an integrated workshop series, a website with topical collections of teaching and career management resources, and a leadership development program. In Cutting Edge 3, the third in a series of collaborative research projects, we expanded our professional development offerings to include more virtual opportunities including hybrid workshops, webinar series, journal clubs, and other virtual events, added assessment projects, and developed and implemented a system for community-review of online teaching materials. We offered more than 40 professional development opportunities including more than 20 face-to-face workshops and more than 20 virtual or hybrid workshops, webinars, journal clubs, or other virtual events. We made a transition to sustainable programming under management of the National Association of Geoscience Teachers (NAGT). To support this transition, we established the NAGT Professional Development Planning Committee, supported the first and second Earth Educators’ Rendezvous to establish it as a sustainable venue for workshop programming, developed a plan for transition of the website to NAGT and initiated this work, and moved forward a fourth implementation of the national geosciences teaching practices survey in collaboration with other NSF-funded geoscience professional development programs.

Intellectual merit: On the Cutting Edge aimed to develop a geoscience professoriate committed to high-quality instruction based on currency in scientific knowledge, good pedagogic practice, and research on learning with the ultimate goal of improving student learning. It expanded the number of geoscience faculty who have had a first Cutting Edge workshop experience, provided advanced opportunities for engagement with the Cutting Edge program that encouraged repeated participation, enabled on-going learning, and resulted in increased changes in teaching practice, and improved the website with expanded community-authored and community-reviewed resources and improved methods for finding materials to more fully support effective geoscience teaching.

The results of data analysis from our 2004, 2009, and 2012 national geoscience faculty teaching practices surveys were written up into a paper by Manduca et al., Improving Undergraduate STEM Education: The Efficacy of Discipline-Based Professional Development, that is in final revision for Science Advances. Survey data show that teaching strategies involving active learning have become more common, that these practices are concentrated in faculty who invest in learning about teaching, and that faculty investment in learning about teaching has increased. Regression analysis shows that faculty who have participated in Cutting Edge programs and who regularly use resources on the Cutting Edge web site are statistically more likely, after controlling for other key influences, to employ active learning teaching strategies. Cutting Edge participants also report that learning about teaching, the availability of teaching resources, and interactions with peers has supported changes in their teaching practice. Our data suggest that even one-time participation in a workshop with peers can lead to improved teaching by supporting a combination of affective and cognitive learning outcomes.

Broader impacts: Overall, On the Cutting Edge has provided professional development opportunities on a variety of topics to 3398 individuals (in 5135 workshop-seats). Participants have come from the spectrum of academic institutions including two-year colleges, liberal arts colleges, comprehensive universities, and research universities. Participants have included 48% women, 8% under-represented minorities, and 16% minorities. Cutting Edge offered annual workshops for Early Career Geoscience Faculty and annual workshops on Preparing for an Academic Career in the Geosciences for graduate students and post-docs. These workshops are continuing beyond the grant, the first is continuing as a stand-alone workshop and the second has transitioned to a workshops embedded in the Earth Educators’ Rendezvous.

The website, On the Cutting Edge: Strong Undergraduate Geoscience Teaching (http://serc.carleton.edu/NAGTWorkshops/index.html) provides integrated access to the results of the workshop programs including topical sites synthesizing workshop findings and references; community-contributed collections of teaching activities, syllabi, books, visualizations, assessments, and more; and full descriptions of the workshops. It supports workshop participants in exchanging and synthesizing ideas, facilitates community research projects, and provides recognition for peer-reviewed teaching materials. The website has grown to over 6100 pages of content. The website was visited by more than 800,000 users in 2015 including over 16,000 sessions that spanned 10 or more pages.

Through the workshops and associated websites, On the Cutting Edge has transformed the way that participants think about their teaching and their specific classroom activities and assessments. It also serves as a source of ongoing professional development that enhances the ability of participants to make use of new teaching techniques, materials, and research findings in response to the changing needs of their students. Cutting Edge websites are widely used beyond the geosciences as evidenced by heavy use of pages on the topical sites of Affective Domain, Metacognition, and other topics of broad relevance in education.
